sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: Let $\mathbb{R}^3$ be the three-dimensional Euclidean space equipped with the Riemannian metric expressed by the matrix $g=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. Find the volume form of this metric.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given Riemannian metric, we first need to compute the determinant of the metric tensor $g$. The determinant is given by:

$$\det(g) = \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - 0\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} + 1\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} = 1(2) - 0(0) + 1(-2) = 0.$$

Now, the volume form is given by the square root of the absolute value of the determinant of the metric tensor, multiplied by the standard volume form in $\mathbb{R}^3$, which is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$:

$$\text{Vol}(g) = \sqrt{|\det(g)|} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = \sqrt{0} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = 0 \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz.$$

Thus, the volume form of the given Riemannian metric is $0 \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$.
